thread: A couple of Alpine festivals in Romandie
post:
6th-7th August in Prégny, Geneva:   Sonalp is a "yodelling Rock band", quite alternative in the world of yodelling. There'll be plenty of beer and Bratwürze! The female yodel choir of Geneva will be there too.     
23rd-24th July in Nendaz, Valais:      
Amazing Alpine horn and yodelling competition, all ending with the qualified horn players playing together around a mountain lake. Even if Alpine horn is not your scene, it is quite breath-taking and ticks all the "stereotypical Swiss boxes"!     
And of course on 1st August in Cologny, from 18h00 onwards, your humble servant McTAVGE will be yodelling for Swiss National Day celebrations as part of the Alphüttli choir, and perhaps even a second EF member will be joining on stage (Peter????)

Hey,    
In Geneva there is an active improv comedy group called Renegade Saints Improv:      
They perform shows once a month from September through June and host regular free drop-in sessions for people who want to try it out just to come and play some improv games and have fun.    
Check out their facebook page which is kept up to date:

The Velodemo held in September is the nearest to what you're seeking. Boom boxes, beers and babes rolling around the city. The police escort the group and close roads. A pleasant way of seeing the city for a couple of hours. I find the critical mass rides a bit raggedy but certainly friendly.    
The style ride baffles me completely but it's harmless.

Le Port de Fribourg (Basse Ville) should have options - although the menu changes every day/week:    
Otherwise, l'Hôtel de Ville has excellent food - and I've seen the chef shopping at the market on Saturday mornings, so the food is definitely fresh! Their lunch deals are really worth it, but you often have to book ahead of time.

In Portugal, the public premiere for the movies of the week is on Thursdays and for each film, one or more cinemas (depending on movie's popularity) is chosen for a preliminary premiere on Wednesday. I often participated in this and actually won a lot of free tickets! So... Somebody knows something similar here in Switzerland? Do you know entities that usually offer tickets or some page that group several of these contests? Especially for Zurich!

thread: Zurich Art Event: Die Lange Nacht
post:
I don't know how many of you Zürich folks know about this already, but we attended last month and it was a great event.  Basically you pay one entrance price (CHF 25) for an armband that gives you access to transportation and all the participating museums, galleries, etc. located all over Zurich.  It's just one time per year but all there were so many places to see that we barely hit 1/2 of the places we planned.     
It's not just art venues, the Zürich Zoo, Corbusier house, Botanical Gardens, Paleontology Museum and Tram museum were just a few other venues participating.  Everything stays open late into the night and there are films, tours and talks at most locations.  I would definitely go again!!    
General Info:    
Program and Venue list:

For the animal lovers, SRF1 is airing a documentary on Oct 25th, 3pm about  , a British writer, whose story inspired the Hollywood film "We bought a Zoo".   
On the topic of touching animal stories, I felt compelled to share two tales of unusual animal friends that just made my week.      met and became friends when they were both one month old. After Fum sadly passed away due to a renal obstruction, his owners took in a new cat, Glac, who also befriended Gebra.    
Jill, a squirrel, who has been rescued by a family after she fell down her nest during a hurricane, seems to like interacting with her  .

Sports yes I would agree great escape. Also 7 pretty girls behind the bar at any given time

thread: Tandoori - The art of BBQ - Restaurant ZH ?
post:
Ok, ladies and gentleman... I have just got back from the very restaurant described in this thread, so lets not waste any time and get on with a frank and honest review from someone who LOVES their curries...   
Well anyway, .  I ordered a take-away from the place and took it home... only to find that what I had thought was a Lamb Rogan Josh, was actually a Lamb Stew, which tasted like it could have been cooked in any one of a gazillion English cafes.   . It was for this reason that I desperately wanted to find somewhere tonight that could change my opinion that Zurich curry houses were not all this bad.  So, I searched the English forum and found the Tandoori BBQ House... and then proceeded to give the manager Sandeep a call to check if we could have a table... but also I mentioned that we were from the English Forum, and I was very encouraged to hear him not only recognise it (as he would, since he has posted in this thread, duh), but that he was open to giving us whatever we wanted curry-wise in order to make it as "UK-like" as possible.  Game on!      .  The place is located literally around 5 minutes from my house on Bleicherweg... the funny thing is that i've walked past it so many times and never give it a second glance... it kind of just looks like a generic cafe form the outside... there's nothing "Indian" about the external decor that would make you think: "Ahh a curry house".  Inside,  .. still no "Indian identity" in the way that many UK indian restaurants have, but then again who gives a crap, it's the food that matters... right?   
The food.... ah... the food.  To start with me and the lovely lady I was with had the usual popadoms and dips, standard fare at any curry place, right?  Well as much as I never usually even take notice of such trivial things as popadoms... these were noteworthy.  We got a good portion of them too, around 10, all perfectly crispy and well-shaped... but the dips?  Well,  , UK included.  One was a thick and rich mint yoghurt, the other a sauce of unknown name and origin (delicious, but can't remember what it was, all I know is i've never tasted it before), and the other was the managers own special "blow your socks off" home-made jobby that literally left me gasping for more... as well as air...  **** me it was hot!    
Anyway since this is dragging on a bit (sorry, but i'm just so happy i've found a good curry house) i'll go on to say that after ogling the menu we ordered a Chicken Tikka Massala (Tandoori style) and a Lambsomething Gosh and were given a choice of "semi-deadly or "deadly" (heh)... we chose "semi-deadly"... best be on the cautious side to start with eh? After an acceptable wait (not too quick, not too long) it arrived... and  .  After getting it served we tucked in and I swear that after three mouthfuls I almost had my first multiple foodgasm.  After 8 months of nary a sniff of a good curry, I was treated to one of the most delicious i'd had in a   time... UK included, which for me is saying a LOT.  The meat was tender and succulent, and  !  In fact I ate well past the point where I felt comfortable, even if only because I felt guilty for leaving it.    
After the meal we were offered two glasses of "Grappa" to aid digestion, which after two beers (which were also delicious, from southern switzerland, never tried that type of beer before, was VERY tasty and smooth) and a mountain of curry actually left me feeling like I was going to collapse... I don't think i've ever been so full in a long time, it was almost situation critical.   
The service from Sandeep was faultless (though to be fair it was a quiet night, being a Sunday, so he had time to spare), and it really helps that he speaks very good English, because the entire meal was fantastic from start to finish in terms of taste and ambience... and even my lady friend, who is possibly one of the worlds anally fussiest people, had nothing but good things to say about it.   
Sorry it's turned into a mini-essay but I really wanted to make a point of writing how happy I am about this place...  , and I was almost full to bursting when I left, which is what I look for in any Indian restaurant.   
9/10 from me...  !    
EDIT - Bolded bits for skim readers who want a quick overview of the place without reading the first chapter of Gone With The Wind.

It's not impossible to get a decent sit-down meal for less than 100 for 2 people. You just need to choose the place carefully and be a little practical. Share a salad (or starter) and the dessert. thread: Conny-Land -- lots to do for a 2.5 yr. old boy?
post:
Well, we finally made it to Conny-Land today, and we all really enjoyed it.    
I was surprised that it wasn't busy, especially since we went on a pleasantly warm, sunny Sunday. We didn't have to wait at all for most rides, and any rides that we did have to wait for, the wait was only a couple minutes or less. My 2 1/2 year-old was thrilled that they have bumper cars as well as some coin-operated cars that he was surprisingly able to drive all by himself. It seems like they are much more relaxed here than they are in the US about height requirements for rides. Of course, though, our little guy wasn't able to ride the roller coaster or a couple of the large rides. But there were still lots of rides for him to enjoy (including both of the water rides).   
It was quite sad to see the empty dolphin pool  , but if they weren't treating the dolphins correctly before, then I'm sure it's best that they no longer have them there.    
The cost was 29 CHF per adult and kids up to the age of 3 are free. The restaurant had a surprisingly nice selection of food at reasonable prices.   
We will definitely go again. I highly recommend this cute little amusement park for anyone with small kids.

thread: Organizing Your Own Wedding. Any tips?
post:
Don't want to rain on your parade.... but in Switzerland you must have a civil ceremony, the church bit is optional. and unlike the UK, for example, it's rare for a church or other venue to be licenced for doing the civil bit as well as the 'social, ceremonial  part' of a wedding.  
So you need to check if there's a list of places that   do both (if that's what you want) with your local Mairie or town hall. Or decide if you just have the civil part, and arrange a big party elsewhere.  
And just to be doubly difficult, they won't usually make bookings for the civil part more than three months in advance, so people often get married and have the church ceremony on two different days!

1.  P rime Steakhouse (Rebgasse 8, 8004 Zurich)     Whats it like inside? Exactly like the sort of place that sells a 150 chf steak; trying to be as elegant as possible in what is basically a carnivores moshpit. Thus we have low lighting, dark-wood banisters, well-placed orchids, and a massive painting of a bull-in-a-noble-situation i.e. not with twenty lances sticking out its arse.     Atmosphere: but you can dim the lights, slice your serious-white tablecloths, and put price lists in brown-leather binders all you like, you're a steakhouse, and the moods delirious: high-pitched yakking, lots of laughing, and etc behaviour inevitable when basically everyone is drinking blood.     Bit weird: the steaks get cooked behind the cramped bar on a smouldering charcoal grill which sounds more 'pre burned-down beach shack' than weighty restaurant in Zurich, but fair's fair it's their place and they can cook their steaks where they like, as long as it's not next to my table like some places, like wtf, give me a mariachi band any day.     Food: theres nothing I can add to the STEAK! RAH! debate, just to say theyre  experts here. So instead its time for todays Most Poignant Thing Ever: although most death-row convicts choose steak for their final meal, most meals are left uneaten.      Service: friendly, smart, relaxed, let you get on with it.     Score: 8/10. Points off for overcharging for dessert (take that Prime Steakhouse). What they didnt know was Id have paid double for their sorbet and vodka in a big glass (take that Prime Steakhouse). Seriously nice vodka used too; drinking only top quality alcohol forever is reason enough to greedily conglomerate your own fortune       Top tip: book well in advance for weekends (like a week plus). The only Zurich steak place you can walk into on weekends is that one in ye olde towne, coz its shit. Weeknights at Prime are busy too.     Directions: Tram stop Stauffacher; named after Werner Stauffacher who in 1307 was Schwyz cantons representative at the legendary Rütlischwur. This is where the Switzerland we know and love began and in typically Swiss fashion, with everyone agreeing to terms and conditions.

I would like to give two thumbs-up to Typisch Thai in Lachen.    
We are expats from Asia living couple of years in Lachen (working in Zurich) we are grateful for the decent Chinese cuisine at Beyond in Zurich town, and the little Korean eatery off Bahnhofstrasse. But we are most thankful for the superb authentic Thai cuisine in our "hometown" of Lachen.   
Typisch Thai is run by Bo (Thai) and her Swiss husband Lukas. Lukas is a professional chef in his own right but leaves the cooking to Bo -- and what wondrous pad thai, larb, som tam, tomyam soup etc she turns out with her staff. You are assured of great Thai dishes daily... or go on Wed and Fri for the eat-all-u-can buffet. Good value with unlimited noodles, rice, spicy soup,3 or more curries, salads etc.   
For a special event though, Lukas can be persuaded to create great desserts like his lava chocolate cake. And if you have a party for 17 and above pax, they will put on a buffet spread. We had a birthday celebration and they made it a special occasion.    
They also run a little lebensmittal shop next door. No need to trek into Zurich for fresh tofu, coriander and other vegetables, curry mixes, frozen seafood supplies...it is such a boon for us that we felt we must share with other expats in the area.

thread: Small, cozy and really italian restaurant in zurich
post:
Having recently "landed" in Zurich from Italy as an expat, I would warmly recommend to all the Italians and the friends of Italy in this Forum the small but excellent Pizzeria Trattoria da Michele, whose philosophy could be summarized in the short statement: Italian cuisine with homemade ingredients, without compromises. It is conveniently located in the zone of Binz-Wiedikon, near to the Uetliberg railway station (UetlibergStrasse 109, 8045 Zurich; tel. 043 960 03 46- closed on Sunday).   As an Italian, I am immediately able to understand if the Italian dishes abroad are made according to what our mothers and wives prepare for us at home, and most often the best I can find is something that can be labeled Italian style. When dining at the restaurant Da Michele this is not the case. And the reason is very simple: the key ingredients and raw materials come from Italy or are purchased from Italians which produce them in Zurich, in compliance with the specifications of our ancient tradition. The quality is therefore unbelievably high.   
Just to give some specific examples: Micheles ravioli di magro ( maultaschen (?) filled with cheese, pumpkin or spinachs) are simply amazing, because they are home-made and always fresh. The same holds for tagliatelle, a kind of ribbon-like pasta that is processed in Italian houses according to secret recipes that every mother trades to her daughter, and so on The Pizza section of the menu is very rich and one appreciates immediately the quality of the real Italian tomato sauce and mozzarella, that I have seen badly imitated in Zurich, sometimes with very terrific outcomes. 
I am not a meat enthusiast, but I see that meat dishes are very praised by other clients.   
Coming from Sicily, don Michele (the owner) gives his best in cooking typical dishes of Southern Italy, sometimes very tasty and very different from Swiss food. Who is not a fitness addict should not miss the Italian dessert (a caloric bomb) at the end, and I suggest to conclude the meal with a real Italian expresso coffee and a small glass of mirto, a typical liquor from our islands, made from an aromatic plant (mirth).  
The restaurant has been opened recently and is still undergoing some upgrade, but can host about 20 people in a very cozy and Italian atmosphere. At noon is known and appreciated by the employees of the neighboring banks, while in the evening it is more frequent to find it hosting also groups of Italian friends, driven by the nostalgia for the Mediterranean sun.  
The owner Michele speaks a good German, and is always courteous and helpful in providing advice on the Italian dishes in the menu. He is assisted by Alexandra, a gorgeous, Pamela Anderson-class (or, for the Italian readers, Valeria Marini-class  ) blonde Hungarian lady, who adds a touch of Eastern European charm to the environment. 
Enjoy your meal!

thread: Another fine dining experience in Fribourg
post:
On Friday night we ate at the  in Fribourg to celebrate a friend's birthday. We were a large group of 15 (inc. children), some of whom had only basic French. However, the staff were incredibly patient, friendly and efficient despite some mind-changing over orders etc. 
I chose the seasonal salad starter and a main course of Steak Tartare Italienne, with slithers of fresh parmesan, flavoured with truffle oil, and served with a small salad and chips. It was bloody delicious; good quality chopped beef with that tasty earthy truffle flavour   (could have done with a little more toast though) 
Other people had the house speciality, entrecote served in the pan with a taragon-flavoured café de Paris. I had a taste of someone's and that too was excellent, cooked by you to your own preference at the table. the moules marinière were also delicious (had a quick taste of those too  ). We'd brought our own birthday cake which they were happy to cut and serve for us. 
We paid 100.- per person, including the wine (which was quite a few bottles, as I recall  ) and are planning to head back for my birthday next month. 
Highly, highly recommended.

thread: Looking for romantic restaurant around lake Zurich
Wow, what a meal. 1* Michelin  at fab value.
post:
Just come back from the Auberge du Bon Accueil, in Malbuisson, by Lac St Point, just over the (Jura) mountain from Nyon. 1 Michelin star and 15/20 at Gault&Millau.   
As it was to celebrate 2 birthdays (missed the opportunity in Feb/March) we pushed the boat out and took the best menus - 87 Euros- for about 7 courses, including 4 different puddings, and 1 glass of fantastic wine with each main course, including Mersault, Fleuirie, Loire Bourgeuil and yellow vin de paille- beautiful decor, mix or rustic and modern and very attentive and yet friendly service. Would highly recommend it. We had Comté feuilletés. wild garlic and cream soup, fera (fish) with mange-tout,  lamb with cabbage and orange zest, a gentian and mandarin sorbet... then pistacchio ice-cream, followed by a choice of amazing desserts then ... sesame tuiles and madeleines with fruit salad!!! All small but perfectly formed portions- fantastic.   
 I asked Mrs FAivre to show me the rooms. The cheaper ones are en-suite but a bit dated and (quiet) roadside at 65E, but the Junior suites are really lovely and on the quiet side, large, mix of rustic and modern, nice bathroom. More expensive but still very reasonable. A couple of minutes walk from the lake, about 10 mins to Pontarlier (and 15 mins from us).   
2 minutes away is another great but very different restaurant  at L'Hotel du Lac, très 'vieille France', Louis XVI furniture, chandeliers, and a fabulous view of the Lake, with rooms with balcony facing the Lake. Visiting both would make such a pleasant contrast. Enjoy. The lake is great for swimming, canoing, windsurfing, sailing, with several rental/school places, and of course a fab area for walking, cycling and cross-country skiing in winter + skating if the conditions are right.   
Have a look :
" today rice and chicken tomorrow  chicken and rice"

thread: New Year's Eve Reccos in Geneva, Lausanne, canton Vaud area
post:
I've had some really great times at Bleu Lezard in Lausanne, on three occasions when I was back home for Xmas.     
Upstairs in the resto they convert it into a disco, and the regular disco/bar downstairs plays more younger generation stuff.   You can slide up and down to both areas.   
Probably too late for a table in the resto for eats, but when they finish the meals the party really begins, and they open the doors for an entry fee for both up and downstairs. Party lasts until dawn....   
There is a great view too to Pont Bessier and the Cathdral all lighted up.   
I have been known to dance on a few tables to some great old funky tunes, so if you see someone acting way too foolish for his middle age, that'll be me,  if I can get over from Oxford that weekend.

thread: Mountain restaurants/auberges in the Jura: reviews
post:
On Sunday night, a few of us decided to go for a snowy walk and reserve a table at one of the remote auberges in the Jura.   
Our experience was SOOO fantastic, that I have to give a special recommendation, and thought I'd do so by leaving space for others to rate their own experiences of mountain restaurants.   
There's no website, but it's called   and is about a 30-45 minute walk from La Givrine train station.    
A friend recommended this place to us and claimed that they had one of the best fondues. Against my better judgment (due to the fact that the Buvette le Vermeilley just up the road had a range of different fondues, and even had a three-in-one-pot option), we put it to the test and we have to agree. The fondue was far better than anything we've ever had before.   
Also, a special insider's tip which some of you may have heard about, is to dip your bread in some kirsch (schnapps not liqueur) just before drenching it in fondue. Out of this world!    
The staff here were also extremely pleasant. We were four: 3 Germans and 1 US/Canadian, and so languages were being thrown around left and right. Although they normally do not stay open on Sunday nights, we chatted with them for hours and they treated us to schnapps and wine on the house as well as a lovely jar of jam.    
In terms of the ambience, it was very warm and cozy - perfect after a few hours of hiking in the cold. Candles light up the entire room and the dining room is a very personable affair. We would have stayed longer if we hadn't a train to catch.   
If you do visit, tell the owners that the Canadian redhead and 3 Germans sent you
I highly recommend this one...it's about 5minutes away from Liestal by bus.

thread: A little disappointed in the EF regarding events!
post:
OP, I'll be brief as I'm on my phone. I think I've seen a few of your events, and forgive me for being blunt, but the ones I remember are quite gimmicky and kitschy... the Spanish night, I'd rather go to a Spanish restaurant, same goes for the Mexican and Indian nights.   
These are the sort of theme nights that'd work well in provincial English town back street pubs but you must remember that most expats in CH are quite sophisticated. Speaking as a food pro I really suggest you up your game.... try a proper traditional English food night, and I'm talking serious quality, Rabbit Pie, Lincolnshire Chine, proper Fish pie etc etc, the type of food that Brits should be proud of and spread the word to the locals as well, they will be surprised!     
I host ploughmans lunches in Rapperswil which is much further than Zurich than you are, we use very high quality ingredients in a simple English way, no gimmicks and I rarely get less than 100 people, some from afar away as Geneva.   
If you'd like me to host one at your pub in the spring get in touch and we can talk. It might help to find out if it is your approach or just location.

thread: Christmas Carols tomorrow in Werdmühleplatz, Zürich (near Rennweg tram-stop)
post:
Just to let any home-sick people know that the choir of St Andrew's Church, Zürich, will be singing ten very well-known English Christmas Carols tomorrow (Saturday 26th Nov) in the "Singing Christmas Tree" in Werdmühleplatz, central Zürich, first at 5:30pm then at 6:30pm (two half-an-hour sets).   
If you want to come and join in, you'd be most welcome, provided you can sing more or less in tune (you can just sing the melody) ! We are meeting at St. Andrew's, Promenadengasse, above Stadelhofen station (about one minute's walk from tram-stop Kunsthaus) at 4pm, where music will be handed out. Then we have to meet next to the tree at 4:45pm to put on pixie cloaks, hats, scarves and gloves that are provided by the organisers. Please PM if you'd like to come, since we need to prepare enough copies for everyone, and we're also supposed to tell them roughly how many people will take part. Also bring a black A4 folder. We have the music and a hole-punch !   
May see you there ! Otherwise drop by the Tree to listen. Plenty of videos of this event on youtube. Just search under "Singing Christmas Tree".   
best wishes,   
eggtenor

thread: Hen Night somewhere in Bern or Murten
post: We've done girls nights out (often Friday) in Lorenzinis, ask for one of their big special rooms upstairs ( it has chandeliers and looks fab) and you can really start your party with dinner and drinks. Then you head downstairs (pretty late!!)and you can also reserve their bar area ( by reserving a bottle of champagne) which has seats and is set off from the dance floor. We've done their 'Celebreighties' over 30's nights but they have other nights other weeks. The upstairs dining room allows for all sorts of fun,(we often have birthday parties with fun 'tasks'..) it's private and I don't think it costs any more. usgang.ch has all the Bern events by calendar so you will be restricted to what's on. We did Liquid too, we had at least 20 for a leaving party and that was wild but ended up really expensive (1500chf!) because they kept filling the ice buckets with drinks!! Whatever you do, have a fab time, good luck

thread: A Recommendation - Extremely Family Friendly Eating in Vaud
post:
Last Sunday we had brunch at La Ferme du Chateau.      
It was delightful! It is set up in such a way that you are able to keep an eye on your children while seating at your table and enjoying the company of your friends and/or family. There is a square yard with tables around the perimeter and then several farm related rid on toys, a swing set, and a playhouse with slide. In addition, there are many fun animals and birds for the children to see - a parrot, llamas, peacocks, and more. The shade availability is also great, which is sometimes a hassle to find for newborns and infants not yet allowed to use sunscreen.   
I will say that the food was not necessarily "amazing." Your standard fare of different breads, cheeses, yogurts, eggs, croissants, etc. It was not bad by any means, just nothing spectacular. However, when considering the fact that I was able to leisurely eat my meal and talk to friends for hours without my toddler or infant pitching a fit, they could have served a crap meal and I'd probably still go again.   
Anyhow, two thumbs up. Now I just need to find the equivalent experience in Canton Zurich.

Just wanted to add that they also have a shop at the top of Rotbuchstrasse near Schaffhauserplatz.   
And the pies are very good, sehr lecker. This is coming from someone from a town where it is a legal requirement that every high street must have at least one pie shop
3 Amigos is ok, nothing special, but nice if you can sit outside in the square

Which reminds me...we should plan another reggae outing soon!!!

thread: Lausanne Fireworks at New Year's Eve
post:
I think most cities outside CH now how to throw a New Years' Party. 
For me, it was summed up by the SSF-DRS television coverage of the turning of the year. 
For the hours leading up to midnight, there was the big, multi-national Germanic-speaking TV extravaganza that is Musikantenstadl -- then 5 mins. before midnight, it switched to a Swiss village church with an organist and a girl playing the alphorn - everyone else had forgotten to turn-up. Then it moved to a restaurant, with a few oldies dancing about a bit, and the younger ones swaying from side-to-side on their chairs, with the traditional Swiss "oom-pah" quartet playing away in the background. Ten minutes later, it went back to Austria (Musikantenstadl), and people having fun, again.  
[N.B. I was subjected to this for the benefit of the wife - the London firework spectacular, was obviously an hour later]. 
When I questioned that this was maybe a bit staid for New Year, my wife replied that this is what the people want and are used to. 
Hopefully in ZH, GE, and BE there was a bit more of a party.

I did the 1CHf breakfast thing on Thursday at Aubonne Ikea.     
It's a great deal, but just a warning, you have to stand in a queue behind the 5 million other people, who all turned up and waited outside for half an hour before opening to get their 1CHf breakfast.     
And these 5 million people take all the time in the world choosing which specific croissant they like the look of, shuffle through every pot of yoghurt to ensure they have their most preferred flavour, then rifle through every pack of cheese to choose which variety they feel like eating that morning, then mosey on over to the one open check out in order to count out twenty 5 centime pieces to pay for it.  And then the next hell is trying to get anywhere near a coffee machine to get your caffiene fix.   
It will take all your will power and every scrap of pre-breakfast energy not to scream into this vortex of hell "HURRY THE F*%K UP!"   
Perhaps, if you are that determined to take advantage of the deal, it's better to have a coffee and bit of breakfast before you leave home to prepare yourself for the ordeal.

thread: Place to eat near Zurich HB tonight Sat. 12th June
post:
Leave the main station and walk across the bridge to Central. Turn right at Starbucks and walk a few yards up Niederdorfstrasse (the pedestrian-only cobbled lane). On your left you will see a Malay/Chinese restaurant called  . It's cheap, clean and serves very nice food. They also do smaller portions for those on a budget.   
If it's Swiss cuisine you're after, go a few yards further up the street to the   beerhall, where you can stuff yourself with variations on flesh, potato and cabbage to your heart's content, then get horribly drunk on Swiss or Belgian beer.   
Neither of these is more than a five minute walk from the station.   
En guete!

I used to be a teacher of salsa, merengue and danzon. I am originally from Mexico and have danced all my life. But now Im into finance and almost have no time to do it. 
However, as I used to do it in the states, I will go to your house and teach you and your friends. For 1,2 or 3 hours from basic to advanced. That way you dont have to feel "embarased". No one is begrudging a worker a decent wage, and I maintain that they should not need to rely on tips. Its obviously up to you when you tip, but for me the whole point of it is to reward someone going beyond the call of duty, often significantly.   
Agreed waiters and waitresses have to put up with a lot, but it goes with the turf.   
I usually tip even in bars by a small amount and significantly where it was a particularly good meal, or more importantly service. To pay the same   every time somewhat defeats the object.   
A friend of mine relates the story where a waitress spilt hot soup into his lap, and when he joked "there goes your tip" she was really upset, and honestly expected to still get one. As it turned out she did by getting the sympathy vote from the rest of the group, but its still bizarre...   
Tipping is an emotional response and its often no good to try and analyse it scientifically. How much to tip ranks right up there with the most popular questions from US visitors to Ewe-rope.   
A surly barman who looks right through you and serves the next swiss-talking people through the door, is going to get a different response from an entertaining cheeky-chappy that bothers to ask how things are going... (Bohemia and Kerala , you can work out which is which)   
Waiting an eternity to get served is unforgiveable in my opinion when the place is not busy. Having worked in a bar you learn to read the "I-want-to-order" signals. Short of waving a napkin as recommended by Michael Winner what can one to deal with it other than reflect your feelings in what you give ?   
dave

There a place in Geneva called l'Age D'Or (golden age), which is just on the other side of the Catholic cathedral from the train station.  They do American style deep-crust pizza in two sizes, 6 and 12 inch.  It's not Giordano's or anything but it's in the ballpark.   
Mostly what we would call Pizza back home is called Quiche or Ramequin here.   
Personally I've long since come to prefer the real deal: Neopolitan style.  Interestingly the closest comparison with a real Neopolitan pizza that you find in the states is the Pizza Hut "thin and crispy".  There's something very interesting that happens with the dough they use in Naples around the crust.  Part of it is the cinders from the wood fire, but there's also the quantity of oil in the dough.  It's really the best (and the original).   
Also, there's a Portuguese bakery on Place Riponne in Lausanne which produces tiny 4" pizza's which could easily be from Chicago.  And of course there's the brewery Café du Chateau at the other end of Riponne which makes pizza with brewer's yeast in the dough, which I believe is probably how the Chicago style pizza originated.  There are still a couple of places in Chicago that use brewer's yeast, particularly Pizzaria Uno.   
One funny thing about defining pizza is that Romans consider foccacia to be pizza, but in Naples they call it "foccacia", so there's some confusion.  In Venice they pre-roll the pizza for you, so if you ask for a pizza you will get something that most Americans will think of as a "wrap".  And you know, it's all really really good.   
-mark

Tickets for the 2009/2010 season went on sale at the end of August this year, for performances to July 2010, so I guess try next August.  We bought all our tickets in September and there were still some goodish seats left all year, but honestly this was a bit late as all the really good, reasonably priced tickets were long gone.   
Don't know about star tenors but they did have some okay tickets left back then for Bartoli in La Cenerentola on 2nd Jan.  We didn't buy at the time as weren't sure where we would be on that date.  Turns out we are here, by beginning Dec they only had listening seats left, but that they had any at all was a surprise to me.    
You can always pop into the box office and ask, they speak perfect English and are happy to help.  Will be open right up to performance start time when there's a gig on, but best to come say 10 minutes before it starts if you have few questions as by then everyone has collected their's for the evening and you won't have an irate queue behind you.  If you do this, get a ticket for the queue even if there's noone else there.  If you don't the staff might be rude to you and may even make you get one.  Pointless, yep, but They Are The Law and will be more helpful if you've followed their rules.      I wouldn't bet on them doing this anytime soon in ZH.  If you buy a programme it's all in German but they always (for all the one's I've bought) have the synopsis in English too.  Seems a waste of CHF10 for a synopsis though when you can Wiki it as WolliH says.  Besides, do you want to be looking at the screen or the stage?  They do some pretty amazing productions here.  Turandot was a spectactular set - grotesque, dark - really brought out the cruelty of the whole play.   
Enjoy

thread: Good and reasonable price Restaurant in Geneva
post: I think you should change the approach. First try to consider of what kind your guests are. If they are in favour of nature etc, you might get along the Arve and look out for a nice place, or make an excursion with the whole party onto the Mount Salève. If people rather might like the lake, go to the Southern side and drive into France. A cousin of me who lives in Coppet takes his guests to that area and according to him there is a number of excellent and reasonable restaurants to be found just a few kilometers "behind" the border. Even if, thanks to Schengen, passengers and private cars no longer are controlled, people ought to have the identity card with them of course. There are also some nice reasonable restaurants down the Rhône almost at that borderline. You might also go towards the airport and almost to the eastern end of it pass through the tunnel onto the French side into Ferney-Voltaire, where you might find some nice restaurants as well. If however, your guests are civil aviation minded, take the road west of the airport into Meyrin and then go right earliest and move ahead to the cosy and nice restaurant of the Aéro-Club which of course is primarily catering for the general public. You there can chose between indoors, outdoors and served plus outdoors /self-service. The ambiance is unique and typically Genèvoise in the best of all ways.
I have been in therapy for months trying to forget that.

Great post Jack.    
I was just thinking about this the other day. I compared Tiffins on Seefeldstrasse (Thai cafe, very quick service) to my favourite Thai Cafe in Melbourne (Chilli Cafe, cnr of Russell and Bourke Streets). The price difference is pretty much double for the same food.  Sfr 16 vs $8 per meal eg: green chicken curry or chicken stir fry. I've not compared for beef or lamb - I guess it would be a lot more different. The other similarity to these two places is that they are pretty basic, maybe a little bit more with Chilli Cafe - but service in minimal.   
Ok, ingredients are also different but I would say the quality is about the same. I find this fair. I'm probably earning about double what I would earn in Melbourne. So going out for me is about the same.    
I wish I remembered what dishes at indian restaurants cost so I could compare but honestly though, I don't think it's that much more.    
Naturally it's easier to find cheap food in Melbourne (eg) than here but cheap food is here. You just have to know where to look. Just like kebab places - they all cost about the same, but you just have to find the one that has good meat instead of the awful processed slab that they shave off.   
Like groceries - taking a walk to the asian side of town (langstr, badenerstr) you just realise that there are other shops with normal veggies and fruits that are a lot cheaper. Many south indian grocery shops do good fish for less than what you'd pay in Coop/Migros. You just have to go further or live there.  (My parents don't shop locally in Melbourne either)   
I earn higher because my time and effort is worth more. I think it's the same case to pay for the services that I enjoy.     
~ Nanda. 
(who still eats out)

Not read the book but as far as I was aware Brits in India in the 19thC liked the native spicy food sp much they wanted their cooks and wives to be able to reproduce it back home. It was a Mr Sharwood who invented/created "curry powder" - a blend of most of the spices used to make an Indian style dish.    
Victorian British dishes with Indian influences include Coronation chicken (I think it's disgusting) and Kedgeree (smoked haddock with curried rice), one of my favourite dishes for anytime of the day - originally a breakfast dish which might sound odd but the Victorians ate Chicken and Mutton curries for breakfast - now that would set you for the day!   
BTW I heard a while back that there are more Indian restaurants in the UK than in India.

thread: I read that Basel used to be full of breweries once
post:
The reason that the choice of beer is getting smaller and smaller every year is because an ever-shrinking number of brewery conglomerates is dominating the market, and because the bottom line is all about economy of scale they are trying to sell more of fewer types of beer.   
This is not a typically Swiss problem but can be found all over the world.    
Being involved in two microbreweries myself, I can say that the market is screaming for more innovation. Most of the big conglomerates don't do enough market reserach and are missing out on their chances. The public is very open and happy to experiment with anything that's new. Both microbreweries I'm involved with have trouble brewing the volume to keep up with demand. They only reason they can't sell more is because of their own logistics. This is why they are both growing like crazy and adding capacity wherever they can. There are new microbreweries cropping up all the time. Okay, some are boring but some are very innovative.   
However, there is only so far that they can grow. If you want to break into the bread and butter sector of selling on-tap in restaurants and bars, it requires some tough negotiations. In the past this was nigh impossible as the breweries were also the real-estate moguls and they told their tenants what beers to sell. Times have changed however with breweries foolishly spinning off their real-estate sectors. Now you can negotiate with most tenants. However, the question is, will they negotiate with you. Gastronomy is in a bit of a recession, and whereas innovation is sorely needed, few are prepared to take the risk of signing an agreement with a microbrewery. For the brewery, this would involve them putting up the funds to furnish the restaurant, provde tables, sunshades etc. This can cost in excess of several 10 000 Franks which may be small change for the big guys but is a substantial risk for the little ones, especially seeing one restauant in three goes bankrupt in the first year.   
So before we see any real breakthrough, the little breweries are going to have to grow a bit more to be able to take this risk.   
I have suggested the idea of making English-style beers at the AGMs of both of the microbreweries I am a shareholder of and the idea was met with enthusiasm but not considered high priority. But maybe some day.   
And if you feel about this the way I do, don't just moan that the others aren't doing anything, but buy shares and bring the topic up.

Visit Old city, and climb the Cathedral (you pay 2 francs to go up and take a look, its really worth it, so do it!)    
Chateau Chillon is just outside of Lausanne, about 30 minutes on the train (maybe less) this is well worth a walk thru too, you will not see history like this anywhere else and its just amazing there...well worth the trip.   
Also climb the old lookout tower, made from wood, its got a giant internal spiral stair and is quite an amazing structure in itself.  You can see ALL of Lausanne from here, really good view right up above the tree tops.   
Head to St. Francois (if you are there on thursday, or saturday) there are farmers markets through the streets, and some of the local artisans will have stuff there for sale too, and there is some awesome food to try, spanish olives and all sorts of amazing curry mixes etc, really nice also!   
Before going clubbing head to "Reflet de Ciel" in Malley (its just back up the hill about 2 minutes walk fromt he malley bus stop, take the number 7 bus) It just serves cocktails, have 2 cocktails there and you wont need to spend a fortune at the clubs on drinks. I recommend the bucaneer....so good.   
Uhm, for going out, head to the Flon area, and go to "Mad", its about 15 franc entry but its 3 levels of different music styles. Not bad. Also there is another club at the Chauderon bus station drop off, just down thestairs on the way to Flon called "The Loft" it's also pretty good there too.   
Flon is really the night club district, I think there are about 3 or 4 clubs in this area. There is another club there that has latin dance upstairs and dance music downstairs, I forget the name to this club sorry...Also La Movida which is at the bus stop just before Chauderon which I now forget! (damnit!) AH I REMEMBERED!! It's Bel Air, just next to the bus stop and the Migros.   
Enjoy!!

There's quite a bit of bland food here. What you or I might call spicy, generally isn't.   
I have found a couple of decent local restaurants who offer to fill your plate again once you are done, as long as you stick to the dish of the day.   
When I first came here I struck up a friendship with an American guy, and his comment was that the Swiss can be too fussy - for example they'll insist on providing you with a sauce when you're in the mood for something plain. (Pet hate of mine, both here and in the UK - French beans overcooked and then covered in butter, with small bits of onion; I like French beans slightly crunchy and with nothing on them.)   
Going back to my American friend again, he managed to organize a Thanksgiving dinner (it was important to him) at a local restaurant, and asked a bunch of us to join him. Yes, the turkey was fine, but they'd run out of potatoes and gave us chips (French fries), somehow thinking that we'd prefer them to the roast/mashed potato he had specified. Well, it wasn't quite right, but it was hard to criticize the restaurant staff since they had clearly gone out of their way to accommodate us.   
To be honest, I've spent too much of my life working away from home, so nowadays don't go to restaurants much. But then again, I once lived in France, so much food out just ain't the same...

I used to have to organize these once in awhile and found that Migros or independent butchers and cheese shops were best and usually most affordable. Migros can do meat and cheese platters, but also have "pain surprise," which are very handy but also easier to budget because they come in cheaper varieties and more expensive ones, meaning cream cheese and herb is a more affordable option than, say, salmon.    
My experience was Globus and anything remotely fancy or unusual was a lot more expensive.   
I always worried about not having enough eats and over-booked wildly until I got the hang of the "margin of absence" Aurora mentions. Absolutely right to say it's smart to have some Pretzels or Grissini handy that you can just pop into a bowl or glass to bulk it up if need be.

thread: Whats a good area in Zürich to go for a night-out?
post:
The Aladdin is opposite the taxi rank (otherwise known as the epicentre of the Swiss heroin scene...allegedly) near the decidedly unsexy sex shops. Aladdin rocks my kebab world because the meat is really lean: a crunchy kebab, full of green stuff and lean veal...mmm. It's about a minute from the Xenix.    
Also, for a full-menu adventure, try the Meridien restaurant for whackula menus from Afghanistan (veggie). Other side of the tracks near the Riff Raff bistro / cinema. Don't expect tablecloths or non-stoned service. It's magnificent. At the end of the meal, you play 'Guess the bill'. The waiter / owner's no idea, so you kinda make it up. Fun and different!

When in St Gallen I prefer to eat upscale or at home (or snack in said focaccieria - i used to live in the building of that place). Nontheless, some cheap central options are     , Marktplatz - italian, pizzeria, its a chain but not such a bad one     , Marktplatz - well, i really prefer more upscale so dont expressly recommend, but they are ok apt at serving tex-mex at reasonable prices and to lots of people at the same time so it is good for groups   , Neugasse - mixed basic menu, some traditional fare, some barfood, good quality for ok prices    or     (same owner) also has food and big outdoor terraces that could be nice. No idea about group capacity though, its been a while.   
If you find yourself without the group and a better budget I recommend   or  . That is good dining.    
Well, enjoy SG.

Carmen     http://www.dianaskitchen.com/page/recipes04/a40226l.htm     Bagels 4 to 4 1/2 cups all-purpose flour  2 packages active dry yeast  1 1/2 cups warm water, about 110°  3 tablespoons sugar  1 tablespoon salt  1 tablespoon sugar   In a mixing bowl, combine 1 1/2 cups of the flour and the yeast. Combine water, the 3 tablespoons sugar, and salt; pour over flour mixture. Beat at low speed of electric mixer for 1/2 minute, scraping bowl a few times. Stir in as much flour as you can mix with a spoon.  Turn out onto a lightly floured board and knead in enough flour to make a moderately stiff dough that is smooth and elastic (about 8 minutes). Cover with a clean towel and let rest 10 minutes.  Cut into 12 equal portions; shape each portion into a smooth ball. Punch a hole in the center of each ball and pull gently to make a 1 1/2 inch hole in the center. Place on a greased baking sheet. Cover and let rise 20 minutes. Broil bagels 5 inches from the heat for 4 minutes, turning once. Tops shouldn't brown.  Heat 1 gallon of water with 1 tablespoon of sugar; bring to a boil then reduce heat. Put bagels in water and begin timing when they rise to the top. Cook about 3 to 4 bagels at a time for about 3 minutes, turning once. Drain. Place on greased baking sheet.  Bake at 375° (190 C) for 25 to 30 minutes. Makes about 1 dozen bagels.

Uhhh... mango desserts.... I supposed i can start dieting tomorrow        I often do a consideralby richer recipe. It is fast, easy and it has never failled me.... Actually, this the a version of the one that is used in mexican restaurants to do what they call "mango mousse" ( technically, it is not a mousse)  You take need: -1 can of condensed milk, - 4 packs of yughurt (light version) or 250mL of cream (hard drugs version) - 1 can of mango pure (or 2 cans of regular mango, and you homogenize it with a thermomixer).  You mix and whip evrything in a bawl. Once it is creamy, you put it in the refrigerator for about 4 hours to cool it down. Done.   An Indian friend gave me this other recipe, that it is a little * lighter * :  You will need 1L of yughurt. Put it to drain on a cheesecloth in the fridge overnight. You do the same to a can of mango pure (or 2 mango cans and then homogenize them with a thermomixer). You might need to discard the liquid a couple of times.   Once decanted, you mix the yugurt and mango pure, and whip untill it is creamy. You can then add 2 spoons of sugar (or whatever you find suitable for your taste), a tea spoon of grounded cardamon and 3-5 threas of safron. Don't forget to "solve* the saffron in 1-2 warm spoons of water for about a couple of hours.   Once everything is mixed, it goes to the refrigerator for about a couple of hours. It is best served with desalted pistachios on top.

Have you ever wondered where you will eat dinner when you are driving back from Italy or Tessin to Zurich or Zug? If you are driving back on a Sunday you've probably been stuck much longer than you planned to be waiting for the Gotthard, and if you've just come back recently you've discovered the lovely road works on the northern side of the Gotthard which add another 45 minutes to your journey (so even if you take the Gotthard pass you'll still be stuck as everything comes down to 1 lane afterwards). So my point is that you may want to make alternative arrangements for dinner.       
Chances are you might pass the Brunnen turn-off depending on the route you have chosen. Take this turn-off and you'll very quickly find yourself with a reasonable choice of restaurants that are open - also late on a Sunday evening. We were surprised at the choice and quality of the restaurants, and they all look out over the lake.   
You can probably guess that I am usually somewhat underwhelmed at the average restaurant experience, so you can imagine my surprise when the Mexican restaurant we selected actually turned out to be quite nice! Fans of Mexican restaurants will know what I'm talking about - they are usually just absolutel rubbish aren't they? Service was friendly, the food was of good quality and the prices semi-reasonable.   
So next time you are doing the trip back my tip is to stop and eat in Brunnen, it's well worth it.   
The place we ate at is called Mezcalito Bodega and Bar, you can find their website at  .   
Do you have another tip for a place to stop on the way back to Zug or Zurich? Share it with us.
